Expounded by Maitreya Bodhisattva

In the first chapter of the first part of the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra, it is asked: What is the stage of the yoga practitioner?
It is said: the seventeen stages.
What are the seventeen?
The uddÄna says:
The stage associated with the five consciousnesses, the mind stage, the three stages of having investigation and analysis, etc.,
The stages of being accompanied by samÄdhi, not being accompanied by samÄdhi, having a mind, and not having a mind,
Established by hearing, thinking, and cultivation - thus, it is endowed with the three vehicles,
Having a basis and not having a basis - these are called the seventeen stages.
The first is the stage associated with the five consciousnesses.
The second is the mind stage.
The third is the stage of having investigation and analysis.
The fourth is the stage of having no investigation but only analysis.
The fifth is the stage of having no investigation and no analysis.
The sixth is the stage of meditative equipoise.
The seventh is the stage of not being in meditative equipoise.
The eighth is the stage of having a mind.
The ninth is the stage of not having a mind.
Tenth, the stage of learning.
Eleventh, the stage of reflection.
Twelfth, the stage of cultivation.
Thirteenth, the stage of Å›rÄvakas.
Fourteenth, the stage of pratyekabuddhas.
Fifteenth, the stage of bodhisattvas.
Sixteenth, the stage with residual connection.
Seventeenth, the stage without residual connection.
Thus, these are briefly explained as the seventeen.
They are called the stages of yoga practitioners.
What is the stage corresponding to the five groups of consciousness?
It refers to the intrinsic nature of the five groups of consciousness.ğŸ”½Their support, their objects,
their associates, and their functions.
This is generally called the stage corresponding to the five groups of consciousness.
What are called the five groups of consciousness?
Namely, eye consciousness, ear consciousness,
nose consciousness, tongue consciousness, and body consciousness.
Form.
Their support refers to
the simultaneous support, which is the eye,
the immediately preceding support, which is the mind,
and the seed support, which is all the seeds.
The support of grasping.
The Älaya consciousness that is included in the retribution.
In this way, the two kinds of supports are briefly explained.
Namely, form and non-form.
The eye is form, the others are not form.
The eye is the four great elements and their derivatives.
The pure form that is the support of eye consciousness.
It is invisible but has resistance.
The mind refers to the eye consciousness that has ceased immediately in the past.
The consciousness that contains all seeds.
It refers to the consciousness that has been the cause of being habituated to conceptual proliferation since beginningless time.
The consciousness that is born from the seeds of retribution that are produced by this cause.
The objects of this consciousness.
Namely, form.
It is visible and has resistance.
This is further of many kinds.
In brief, there are three kinds.
Namely, color, shape, and informative form.
Color refers to
blue, yellow, red, and white.
Light, shadow, brightness, darkness,
clouds, smoke, dust, and mist.
And the single color of space.
Shape refers to
long, short, square, round,
coarse, fine, regular, irregular, high, and low colors.
Informative form refers to
Namely, grasping, releasing, bending, and stretching.
Walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.
Such forms and so on.
Moreover, the visible form is:
That which is clearly manifest and is the object of the eye consciousness.
The shape is:
That which is accumulated and has the characteristics of long, short, etc.
The informative form is:
That which is the arising and ceasing of this accumulated form.
Due to the cause of transformation, it does not arise again in the place where it originally arose, but transforms to another place.
Either without interval or with interval,
Either near or far, it arises with distinctions.
Or it arises with transformation right in this place.
This is called the informative form.
Moreover, the visible form is:
Such distinctions as light and so on.
The shape is:
Such distinctions as the accumulation of long, short, etc.
The informative form is:
The distinctions of movement based on the function of action.
All these visible, shaped, and informative forms
Are the objects of the eye.ğŸ”½The domain of the eye.ğŸ”½The objects of the eye consciousness.
The domain of the eye consciousness.
The objects of eye consciousness.ğŸ”½The objects of mental consciousness.ğŸ”½The objects of mental consciousness.
The objects of mental consciousness.
The distinctions in names.
Moreover, this form is also of three kinds.
That is to say, if it is a good apparent color,
if it is a bad apparent color,
if it is an apparent color that is different from both.
It appears similar to form.
Its associates are
the mental factors that are concomitant with it.
They are
attention, contact, feeling, perception, and volition.
And the other mental factors that are concomitant with eye consciousness.
Moreover, those dharmas have the same object,
but not the same aspect.ğŸ”½They arise simultaneously and in association, but each functions separately.
Moreover, all of them arise from their own seeds.
As for their functions,
it should be understood that there are six kinds.
That is to say, only distinguishing its own object and support,
this is called the initial stage of practice.ğŸ”½Only distinguishing its own characteristics,
only distinguishing the present,
It only has one moment of cognition.
There are also two kinds of actions:
That is, following the mental consciousness,
Following good and defiled [afflictions],
Following the action of giving rise [to karma].
Moreover, it is able to take on the fruits of love and non-love.
This is the sixth action.
What are the five characteristics of the ear consciousness? The self-nature of the ear consciousness is:
That which is based on the ear and distinguishes sounds.
As for its basis, it is the co-existent basis.
That is, the ear.
The immediately preceding basis.
That is, the mind.
The seed basis.
That is, the Älaya consciousness that contains all seeds.
The ear is that which is created from the four great elements.
The pure form that is the basis of the ear consciousness.
It is invisible but has resistance.
The mind and seeds are distinguished as before.
As for its objects, they are sounds.
They are invisible but have resistance.
Moreover, they are of many kinds.
Like the sounds of conches and horns, the sounds of large and small drums,
The sounds of dancing, singing, and various musical instruments,
The sounds of women, men, and the cries of actors,
The sounds of wind, forests, and so forth.
clear sounds and unclear sounds.
meaningful sounds and meaningless sounds.
low, medium, and high sounds.
sounds of rivers, etc.
sounds of quarrels and commotion.ğŸ”½sounds of upholding and expounding.
sounds of discussing and discerning.
There are many such categories of sounds.
This is briefly of three kinds.
Namely, sounds caused by the great elements that are grasped.ğŸ”½Sounds caused by the great elements that are not grasped.
Sounds caused by the great elements that are both grasped and not grasped.
The first is only internal sounds.
The next is only external sounds.
The last is internal and external sounds.
This is further of three kinds.
Namely, agreeable sounds.ğŸ”½Disagreeable sounds.
Sounds that are both agreeable and disagreeable.
Moreover, sound isğŸ”½The different names for cries, sounds, words, roars,
and expressions.
This is what the ears engage in.
The objects of the ears.
What the ear consciousness engages in.ğŸ”½The objects of the ear consciousness.
What is cognized by the ear consciousness.
What is engaged by the mental consciousness.
The objects of the mental consciousness.
The objects of the mental consciousness.
The associates and actions should be understood as in the case of eye consciousness.
What are the five characteristics of olfactory consciousness? The intrinsic nature of olfactory consciousness.
It is the faculty of the nose that distinguishes smells.
Its basis.
The simultaneous basis.
It is the nose.
The immediately antecedent basis.
It is the mind.
The seed basis.
It is the Älaya consciousness that contains all seeds.
The nose is a pure form that is the basis of olfactory consciousness, which is composed of the four great elements.
It is invisible but has resistance.
The mind and seeds are distinguished as above.
Its objects are smells.
They are invisible but have resistance.
They are of many kinds.
They are good smells, bad smells, and neutral smells.
They are the smells of roots, stems, flowers, leaves, and fruits that are smelled by the nose.
There are many kinds of smells like this.
Moreover, smells.ğŸ”½They are what is smelled by the nose.
They are what is grasped by the nose.
They are the different names for what is smelled by the nose and so on.
These are what the nose experiences.
They are the objects of the nose.ğŸ”½They are what the nose consciousness experiences.ğŸ”½They are the objects of the nose consciousness.
They are what the nose consciousness takes as its object.ğŸ”½They are what the mental consciousness experiences.ğŸ”½They are the objects of the mental consciousness.
They are what the mental consciousness takes as its object.
The associates and actions should be understood as before.
What is the essence of tongue consciousness?
It is the faculty of the tongue that distinguishes tastes.
Its basis is:
The simultaneous basis.
It is the tongue.
The basis of the immediately preceding moment.
It is the mind.
The basis of seeds.
It is the Älaya consciousness that contains all seeds.
The tongue is a product of the four great elements.
It is the pure form that is the basis of the tongue consciousness.
It is invisible but has resistance.
The mind and seeds should be distinguished as before.
Its objects are tastes.
They are invisible but have resistance.
They are also of many kinds.
They are bitter, sour, spicy, sweet, salty, and bland.
They are agreeable, disagreeable,
or neutral. They are what the tongue experiences.
Moreover, tastes are:
That is to say, one should taste, swallow, chew,
drink, lick, suck, and enjoy.
Such distinctions in namesğŸ”½are what the tongue experiences.
They are the objects of the tongue.ğŸ”½They are what the tongue consciousness experiences.ğŸ”½They are the objects of the tongue consciousness.
They are what the tongue consciousness cognizes.ğŸ”½They are what the mental consciousness experiences.ğŸ”½They are the objects of the mental consciousness.
They are what the mental consciousness cognizes.
Their associates and functions should be understood as before.
What is the essential nature of body consciousness?
It is the discrimination of tangibles that is dependent on the body.
As for its basis,
the simultaneous basis
is the body.
The basis of the immediately antecedent condition
is the mind.
The basis of seeds
is the Älaya consciousness that contains all seeds.
The body is what is created from the four great elements.
It is the pure form that is the basis of body consciousness.
It is invisible but has resistance.
The mind and seeds should be distinguished as before.
As for its objects,
they are tangibles.
They are invisible but have resistance.
They are of many kinds.
Namely, earth, water, fire, and wind.
Lightness, heaviness, smoothness, roughness,
cold, hunger, thirst, satiation,
strength, weakness, slowness, quickness, illness, aging, death, itching,
dullness, stickiness, fatigue, shortness of breath, softness, timidity, courage,
and so on. There are many kinds of touches like this.
This is further divided into three types.ğŸ”½Namely, good touch, bad touch,
and neutral touch.
What is touched by the body.
Moreover, touch means
what is rubbed and what is touched.
Whether hard, soft, moving, or warm,
such distinctions in names
are what the body experiences.
The domain of the body.
What is experienced by the body consciousness.ğŸ”½The domain of the body consciousness.
What is perceived by the body consciousness.
What is experienced by the mental consciousness.
The domain of the mental consciousness.
What is perceived by the mental consciousness.
The associates and actions should be understood as before.
If it is not properly produced,
the eye consciousness that is produced will definitely not arise.
The eye must be intact,
and the form must be present.
The attention that can produce [the eye consciousness] must also be present.
and is just now arising.
The eye consciousness that is produced
can only be produced.
Just as eye consciousness arises,
one should understand that the body consciousness is also like this.
Next, due to the arising of eye consciousness,
three minds can be obtained.
In their sequence,
they are the spontaneous mind,
the seeking mind,
and the determining mind.
The first is eye consciousness,
the second is in mental consciousness.
After the determining mind,
there is then defilement and purity.
After this, there is the flowing eye consciousness,
turning towards the wholesome and the unwholesome.
But that is not due to the power of its own discrimination.
Until this mind does not turn to another object,
for that length of time,
the eye and mental consciousnesses,
either wholesome or defiled, continue to arise.
Just as eye consciousness arises,
one should understand that the body consciousness is also like this.
Next, one should contemplate the support of the five consciousnesses,
like what is ridden by one who goes to another place.
The object is like what is done.
The associates are like companions.
Karma is like one's own function.
There is another distinction.
One should observe the support of the five consciousnesses.
Like a householder's home.
The object is like what is enjoyed.
The associates are like servants, etc.
Karma is like function.
In the stage of the mental ground of the basic section, it is said that the stage associated with the five consciousnesses is already explained.
What is the mental ground?
This should also be known through five aspects.
Namely, in terms of its intrinsic nature,ğŸ”½in terms of its support,ğŸ”½in terms of its objects,
in terms of its associates,
and in terms of its functions.
The nature of being the support that is followed by all seeds.
The nature of being the support that is adhered to by what is followed.
The essence that is able to grasp.
The Älaya consciousness that is included in retribution.
The mind refers to the constantly active mind and the mind that has just ceased of the six consciousnesses.
Consciousness refers to the present discrimination of the objective realm.
The support and its support refer to
the immediately preceding support.
It refers to the mind.
The basis of seeds.
It refers to the Älaya consciousness that contains all seeds, as explained above.
The objects of cognition and their objects.
It refers to all phenomena, as appropriate.
If it is not shared, the objects of cognition are
the aggregates of feeling, perception, and formation, the unconditioned,
the invisible, and the unimpeded form.
The six internal sense bases and all seeds.
The associates and their associates.
It refers to attention, contact, feeling, perception, and volition.
Desire, resolve, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.
Faith, shame, conscience, absence of greed, absence of hatred, and absence of delusion.
Vigor, tranquility, non-negligence, equanimity, and non-harming.
Greed, anger, ignorance, pride, views, and doubt.
Anger, resentment, concealment, spite, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, flattery, arrogance, and harmfulness.
Lack of shame and lack of conscience.
Dullness and agitation.
Lack of faith, laziness, and negligence.ğŸ”½Wrong desire, wrong resolve, forgetfulness, distraction, and incorrect knowledge.
Regret, drowsiness, reflection, and investigation.
Such things as these.
The associated dharmas that exist simultaneously with the mind,
are called its associates.
They have the same object but not the same aspect,
existing simultaneously,
each revolving separately,
arising from their own seeds,
mutually corresponding.ğŸ”½They have aspects,
have objects,
and have supports.
As for their functions,
they are able to cognize and discriminate their own objects and bases.
This is called the initial stage of practice.
They are also able to cognize and discriminate their own characteristics and common characteristics.
They are also able to cognize and discriminate the past, future, and present.
They are also able to cognize and discriminate in a single moment,
or in a continuous series.
They also give rise to the functions of all pure and impure dharmas, which revolve around them.
They are also able to take on desirable and undesirable fruits.
They are also able to attract other forms of consciousness.
They are also able to give rise to the continuous flow of other forms of consciousness as their causes.
Other forms of consciousness,
have superior functions.
They are able to discriminate their objects,
and carefully consider their objects.
If one is drunk or insane,
Whether in dreams or in the waking state,
whether in a daze or in full consciousness,
if one is able to give rise to bodily or verbal actions,
if one is able to attain separation from desire or fall back from separation from desire,
if one severs the wholesome roots or reconnects with the wholesome roots,
if one dies or is reborn, and so forth.
How is the object of perception discriminated?
By means of seven kinds of discrimination.ğŸ”½Namely, discrimination with characteristics,ğŸ”½discrimination without characteristics,
spontaneous discrimination,ğŸ”½seeking discrimination,
scrutinizing discrimination,ğŸ”½afflicted discrimination,
and unafflicted discrimination.
Discrimination with characteristics meansğŸ”½the discrimination that arises in those who have previously experienced meanings and whose faculties are complete,
and in those who are skilled in language.
Discrimination without characteristics meansğŸ”½the discrimination possessed by those who follow what has been previously drawn out,
and by infants and others who are unskilled in language.ğŸ”½Spontaneous discrimination meansğŸ”½the discrimination that occurs spontaneously in relation to present objects,
in accordance with the power of the objects.
The discriminating conceptualization of searching is as follows:
It refers to the discriminating conceptualization that arises from investigating and searching for various dharmas.
The discriminating conceptualization of scrutiny is as follows:
It refers to the discriminating conceptualization that arises from scrutinizing and establishing what has already been investigated and searched for.
The defiled discriminating conceptualization is as follows:
It refers to the discriminating conceptualization that occurs in association with longing for the past,ğŸ”½with anticipation for the future,
and with attachment to the present.ğŸ”½Whether it is discriminating conceptualization of desire,
discriminating conceptualization of anger,ğŸ”½or discriminating conceptualization of harmfulness,
it is the discriminating conceptualization that arises in association with any of the fundamental or secondary afflictions.
The undefiled discriminating conceptualization is as follows:
It refers to the wholesome or indeterminate discriminating conceptualization.
It is the discriminating conceptualization of renunciation,ğŸ”½the discriminating conceptualization of non-anger,
and the discriminating conceptualization of non-harmfulness.

It is the discriminating conceptualization that occurs in association with any of the wholesome dharmas such as faith,ğŸ”½or the discriminating conceptualization that occurs in the realm of deportment, in the realm of craftsmanship,
and in the various transformations.
This kind of class is called the object of discrimination.
What is the object of careful consideration?
It refers to that which is drawn by proper reasoning, that which is drawn by improper reasoning, and that which is drawn by neither proper nor improper reasoning.
That which is drawn by proper reasoning means not adding what does not truly exist,
like the four inverted views.
That is, regarding what is impermanent as permanent, regarding what is suffering as happiness,
regarding what is impure as pure, and regarding what is non-self as self.
It also does not diminish what truly exists,
like the various wrong views.
That is, the practices of wrong views such as there is no giving, etc.
Or the knowledge of the abiding of dharmas,
truly understands all knowable things.
Or the pure supramundane knowledge,
truly realizes all knowable dharmas.
This is called drawn by proper reasoning.
It should be known that the opposite is drawn by improper reasoning.
That which is drawn by neither proper nor improper reasoning isğŸ”½.
It refers to the discernment of dharmas based on indeterminate wisdom.
This is called the object of careful consideration.
What is intoxication?
It refers to becoming intoxicated due to the weakness of one's nature,
or due to not being accustomed to drinking,ğŸ”½or due to drinking excessively,
or due to drinking beyond one's capacity.
What is madness?
It refers to the onset of insanity due to the attraction of past karma,
or due to the disorder of the elements,
or due to fear and loss of mind,
or due to being struck by a massage stick,
or due to being possessed by ghosts and spirits.
What is dreaming?
It refers to the weakness of one's nature,
or due to the fault of excessive fatigue,
or due to the heaviness of food,
or due to contemplating in the dark,
or due to resting from all activities,
or due to being accustomed to sleep,
or due to being aroused by others,
such as by fanning,ğŸ”½or by spells,
or by medicine,
Or by the power of the gods.
And give rise to confused dreams.
What is awakening?
It means that one who is excessively sleepy is unable to endure fatigue.
Because one who has something to do must sleep.
Or one is awakened from a dream by being led by others.
What is fainting?
It means that due to the disturbance of wind and heat,
Or due to beating,
Or due to purgation,
Like excessive diarrhea and bleeding,
Or due to extreme hard work, one faints.
What is regaining consciousness?
It means to recover from fainting.
What is the arising of bodily and verbal actions?
It means that because the wisdom that gives rise to bodily and verbal actions precedes,
Next, because of the desire to be born,
Next, because of the arising of effort,
Next, in accordance with the wind of bodily and verbal actions that turns due to the priority of effort,
From this, bodily and verbal actions arise.
What is detachment?
It means that because one is endowed with faculties that accord with detachment,
And because one obtains teachings that accord with it from others,
Because one is far removed from those hindrances.
Correctly cultivating skillful means.
Because of correct contemplation.
One is then able to be free from desires.
How does one regress from being free from desires?
It is said that because one's faculties are naturally dull.
One who newly cultivates wholesome practices.
Because one frequently contemplates their appearance and characteristics.
Because one accepts and practices the dharmas that accord with regression.
Because one is obstructed by afflictions.
Because one is embraced by bad friends.
One regresses from being free from desires.
How does one sever the roots of goodness?
It is said that one of sharp faculties.
Because one accomplishes the uppermost evil intentions and practices.
Because one obtains the accord with those bad friends.
Because that evil view entwinement is extremely heavy, perfect, and ultimate.
Because one obtains fearlessness in all evil practices.
Because one lacks compassion.
One is able to sever the roots of goodness.
Herein, the seeds are also called the roots of goodness.
Non-greed, non-hatred, etc. are also called the roots of goodness.
But it is only by establishing the presently practiced roots of goodness.
The continuity of the wholesome roots is severed by a contradiction.
It is not because the seeds are permanently uprooted.
How does one reconnect with the wholesome roots?
It is said that it is because of having a sharp faculty by nature,
seeing close friends and companions cultivating merit,
going to good people and hearing the true Dharma,
because of these causes one gives rise to doubt and attains certainty,
and thus reconnects with the wholesome roots.
What is death?
It is because the lifespan is exhausted that one dies.
This is of three kinds.
Because the lifespan is exhausted,
because merit is exhausted,
and because of not avoiding inequality.
One should know that this is also timely and untimely death.
Either because of a wholesome mind, an unwholesome mind, or a neutral mind.
What is death because the lifespan is exhausted?
It is like when someone dies because the lifespan that was received is completely exhausted.
This is called timely death.
What is death because merit is exhausted?
It is like when someone dies because of a lack of resources.
What is death because of not avoiding inequality?
As the World-Honored One said, there are nine causes and nine conditions.
One dies before one's life span is exhausted.
What are the nine?
They are: eating without moderation,
eating what is unsuitable,
eating undigested food again,
giving rise to [impurities] but not expelling them,
retaining them when they are ripe,
not seeking medical treatment,
not knowing what is beneficial or harmful to oneself,
and engaging in non-celibate conduct at inappropriate times and in inappropriate ways.
This is called untimely death.
What is death with a wholesome mind?
It is like when someone is about to die,
they recall the wholesome teachings they have previously practiced,
or others cause them to remember.
Because of this cause and condition,
at that time, faith and other wholesome teachings manifest in the mind,ğŸ”½up to when coarse thoughts manifest.
When subtle thoughts manifest,
the wholesome mind is abandoned and only a neutral mind remains.
Why is this so?ğŸ”½At that time,
they are unable to recall even the wholesome teachings they have previously practiced.
Others also cannot cause them to recollect.
How does one die with an unwholesome mind?
It is like a person whose life is about to end.
They themselves recollect the evil dharmas they have been accustomed to in the past.
Or perhaps others cause them to recollect.
At that time, unwholesome dharmas such as greed and hatred accompany the mind.
Up to the arising of coarse and subtle thoughts.
As explained well before.
Also, when one dies with a wholesome mind, one dies peacefully.
When one is about to end one's life, extreme painful feelings do not oppress the body.
When one dies with an unwholesome mind, one dies in agony.
When one is about to end one's life, extremely heavy painful feelings oppress the body.
Also, when one dies with a wholesome mind, one sees unconfused forms.
When one dies with an unwholesome mind, one sees confused forms.
How does one die with a neutral mind?
It refers to one who practices wholesome or unwholesome [actions], or one who does not practice [either].
When one is about to end one's life, one cannot recollect [oneself].
There is no one else who can cause one to recollect.
At that time, it is neither a wholesome mind nor an unwholesome mind that dies.
Having neither a peaceful death nor a painful death, and also practicing wholesome and unwholesome persons when they are about to die,
either naturally recollecting the wholesome and unwholesome that they have previously practiced,
or being caused by others to recollect.
At that time, for the one whose power of having long practiced is the strongest,
their mind is biased towards that recollection and forgets all the rest.
If both are equal in having long practiced,
at that time,
according to the first, either they themselves recollect or are caused by others to recollect.
Only this is not abandoned, and no other mind arises.
At that time, due to the power of two causes, they then die.
Namely, the power of delighting in frivolous discourse as a cause,
and the power of pure and impure karma as a cause.
Having experienced the results attracted by previous karma,
if one practices unwholesome karma,
at that time,
they will experience the signs of the unloved results obtained from the unwholesome karma they have previously created.
It is like seeing countless strange and unusual forms in a dream.
Based on this, the Blessed One said:
If one has previously committed evil and unwholesome actions,
and has increased them,
then at that time, like the shadows of the later part of the day or the peaks of mountains covering, completely covering, and completely covering everything,
one should know that such a person goes from light to darkness.
If one first exhausts the fruits of unwholesome actions and cultivates goodness, it is the opposite of the above.
One should know that such a person goes from darkness to light.
The difference here is:
When one is about to die,ğŸ”½it is like seeing countless pleasant forms in a dream,
not strange and unusual forms.
If one commits extremely unwholesome actions,
because of seeing these strange and unusual forms,
one sweats, one's hair stands on end, one's hands and feet are in disarray, and one loses control of one's bowels and bladder.
One gropes in empty space, rolls one's eyes, and foams at the mouth.
At that time, such strange and unusual forms arise in one.
If one creates a middling degree of unwholesome karma,
at that time the signs of strange events may be present or absent.
Even if there are, they are not complete.
Moreover, when sentient beings are about to die,
up to the stage of unclear thoughts,
the habitual present activity of self-love for a long time,
by the power of this, thinks I will not exist.
Then, it loves one's own body.
By this, the intermediate existence and the retribution of rebirth are established.
If it is the fruit of stream-entry or the fruit of once-returning,
at that time, self-love also presently operates.
However, this stream-enterer and once-returner,
by the power of wisdom, repeatedly investigates and controls this self-love, not becoming attached to it.
It is like a strong man competing in strength with a weak person, able to subdue them.
One should know that the principle here is also like this.
If it is the fruit of non-returning,
at that time, self-love does not presently operate.
Moreover, it cuts the limbs and joints.
Except for gods and hell beings,
The remaining birth places all have both.
This is further divided into two types:
heavy and light.
Heavy refers to those who commit evil deeds.
Light refers to those who commit good deeds.
In Uttarakuru, all are light.
Moreover, when dying from the form realm, all faculties are complete.
When dying from the desire realm, faculties may or may not be complete.
Moreover, those who die with pure liberation
are called those who die well-disciplined.
Those who die with impure non-liberation
are called those who die undisciplined.
Moreover, when about to die,
those who commit evil deeds
have consciousness leave the support from the upper part.
Cold sensation arises accordingly from the upper part.
In this way, it gradually leaves up to the heart.
Those who commit good deeds
have consciousness leave the support from the lower part.
Cold sensation arises accordingly from the lower part.
In this way, it gradually leaves up to the heart.
It should be known that the final consciousness leaves only at the heart.
From this, the cold touch pervades the basis.
How does it arise?
Because it arises immediately after self-love.
Because the causes of attachment to conceptual proliferation since beginningless time have been perfumed.
Because the causes of pure and impure karma have been perfumed.
The basis of those, by the power of the two kinds of causes,
